1:57:45 these particular solutions can't really exist no? if there are two free variables, then the last 2 numbers in the particular solution vector has to be zeros. Is that true?   About the plane in this example: the original system of equation that produced this solution set has 3 total variables, two of them are free variables, so this system has only 1 linearly independent basis vector. Which means this system is a transformation of the 3D space into a 1D line that exists in the 3D space and points in the direction of the basis vector. Basically it squashes the 3D space into a line.   So can we think of the plane created by the solution set as "scanning" the 3D space as the particular vector changes? The particular vector will change if we leave the left side (representing the matrix) of the equation alone, and only change the numbers on the right side (representing a vector after transformation), not all numbers (vectors) will be valid in this case, as many will be outside the span of the matrix, but there are infinitely many that are within the span and are valid.  SO. Each and every single vector within the span of this matrix (the line cutting through 3D space) has an entire infinite plane of vectors that were all "squashed" down or mapped into it. And the particular solution simply leads you to this plane of vectors... so you can imagine all of the 3D space as infinitely many planes that were all transformed/squished into the infinitely many vectors of this line.. What do you do to review?

@thatonemailbox  Hey, my job involves Numerical Linear Algebra (Financial engineering) and I had little to no maths background after finishing my MSc so had to self-teach all of LA, real analysis, complex analysis, multivariate calc, stochastic calc, probability and measure theory, etc... Just wanted to say the best way to "review" as such, in my opinion, is to find a way to generate questions which relate to the topic you are studying - whether from textbooks, such as the legendary Gilbert Strang's or even using AI prompts to generate. Make sure they have answers, but go through and answer a few questions, then mark, then highlight any questions you didn't get right, identify the weaknesses and review the relevant content. Reviews should be efficient in order to maximise information retention and should involve some creative use of the techniques you learn, really think about how you could apply these techniques in your own interests. Review frequency should be after a few hours, a few days, then taper accordingly till you only need to review maybe every few months.

What is the rationale behind starting with systems of linear equations without any linear algebra theory? I find it so counterintuitive, because this way the student has no idea what is going on, e.g. that the solution is composed of two pieces, one being homogeneous (i.e. a whole subspace) and the other some constant translation (please excuse my imprecise formulation, I have taken linear algebra in Czech and thus I lack English terminology. At least that is something valuable to get from the video). Teaching systems of linear equations without understanding matrices as transformations, knowing its properties (and properties of its kernel and image, hopefully the English vocabulary includes these two terms as well), the determinant, decomposition of a vector into linear combination of bases etc. feels straight stupid. I have watched the first hour and this problem is poinfully obvious, because many results (e.g. that the solution is composed of homogeneous and particular part or the definition of singular matrix which is straight stupid) and methods are presented without reasonable explanation, why. Without this deeper understanding, the lecture is more like better high school math, not college level. Just as a background, I do not study pure mathematics; I'm aiming for bachelor's degree in cybernetics at CTU in Prague. Even an engineer deserves to understand why, but this course presents only the how of systems of linear equations. I did not watch the rest of video yet, but will prefer something with better structure.
